The 'President of the French Republic' ( ; ) colloquially referred to in English
as the 'President of France', is the head of state, supreme commander-in-chief
of the French Armed Forces. The president's powers, functions and duties, and
their relation with French governments differed with the various French
constitutions.

The president of France is also the ex officio Co-Prince of Andorra, Grand
Master of the LÃ©gion d'honneur and the Ordre national du MÃ©rite and honorary proto-
canon of the Basilica of St. John Lateran in Rome.

The current President of the Republic is FranÃ§ois Hollande, who took office on
15 May 2012.
